title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
Ok so this board has been thru hell :/
Had water damage. Fixed water damage and it worked perfectly. Was putting back in top case and there was a bee in my room and I kinda maybe might have thrown the board at the bee :p and surprisingly everything still worked perfectly except the backlight. I bought a BY-3200 cable so I could test voltages and such outside of the top case and this was my first time using it. I plugged it in, checked a few rails, then was looking at the board view on my laptop when I heard a pop and saw the magic smoke. I have no idea where it came from. Nothing was warm and no components look damaged. It was in this general area though. And like I said it looks like hell lmao I was a lil bit drunk cuz it was pissing me off. It's a personal board, not a customer one. I'm not that unprofessional. I feel like I need to figure out what went poof before I figure out the backlight problem but honestly idk what to do as I don't see anything visible. But it came from the general area I was probing with the backlight components.

[ATTACH type="full"]60791[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]60790[/ATTACH]

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
You must check F8400 first.
If burnt, check for short on several points of backlight circuitry.

Be aware, 3V3_G3H_RTC power supply is very close.
Leakage from backlight output can kill the board.
Board still works, only missing backlight?

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 92731, member: 682"]
If burnt, check for short on several points of backlight circuitry.
[/QUOTE]
nope not burnt. but damn I totally molested this board :/
I think I may have actually put D8410 on backwards. Can you confirm? Also note L8450 and C8463 are off the board. Neither should be crucial for display backlight though. I think. Since I'm not putting a load on C8463 just probing display pins.[ATTACH type="full" alt="IMG_0667.jpeg"]60792[/ATTACH]

Edit: forgot to say I haven't put the board back in the top case and tested if it boots since the magic smoke

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
You can't test the backlight circuit without connecting the internal LCD!

"I may have actually put D8410 on backwards."
Yeah, unfortunately; check if still good.

message: I wouldn't get voltage on the display backlight pins without being connected?

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
Ok so I hook it all up and it fucking worked. All this time it was just that diode =/
Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhhhhhh I'm literally crying lmfao

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message: Weird update. Noticed LB7000 and L3500 look kinda funky. Shown is LB7000, L3500 is not as bad. Any idea what would cause this? Good to just replace or is something else the root cause and gonna make it happen again? They're both USBC related. Neither is near where I saw the magic smoke before though so I don't think thats what it's from.[ATTACH type="full"]60794[/ATTACH]

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
No big problem if coils enclosure is damaged.
I bet the core is OK.

L3500 and LB700 provide power for USB devices connected to the machine.
Check if an USB mouse, or pendrive work properly; test the 4 ports.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
Ok well that didn't last long :/
While testing the machine the display just died on me. Power cycle brings me back to my original issue, image but no backlight. Pulled the board back out and both rows of backlight caps are short to ground. I'm still terrible at understanding schematics lol. A little help on where to check would be greatly appreciated. thx.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
What is the exact resistance to ground (ohm scale) on backlight output?
Check with internal LCD disconnected.
Inspect J8500 for damage.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
LCD connector has no damage, looks perfect. 

PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is 12 ohm to ground

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
Ok I'm pretty dumb. Checked all the backlight caps again and one WAS bad :/
One was also bad before when I was fixing the initial water damage though. Is there something else wrong that is potentially killing these caps? Or is it just bad luck?

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message: Change any cap which looks affected by liquid, on the backlight output.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message: Yeah I changed them, they're all good now. Went to test and omfg this shit making me want to punch a hole in the wall. How tf does this happen? The fucking speaker amp is foaming. WHAT THE FUCK. I'm going to go cry now :([ATTACH type="full"]60795[/ATTACH]

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
Oooops!
The speaker amplifiers are powered from PPBUS_G3H and have direct connection with T2.
Leakage caused by corrosion can kill T2; sometime only losing sound on speakers.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
Still no backlight. Back at this board because my A1706 is annoying the shit out of me. Basically impossible to use while charging on the left side. I fixed it twice and it worked fine for a couple days then back to the same issue. Rather than fixing it right now I'd like to just upgrade to this A2141 because I can't afford another system lmao. But here's some voltages I've gathered. Q8400 has also been replaced. Honestly I'm at a loss for what the problem is.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
Do you still get image, only missing backlight?
Check if DP_INT_HPD is present.
I recommend to test with known good LCD assembly.

Edit: 5v on all ports
Edit 2: ok so ppbus_g3h is short to ground

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
What is the exact resistance to ground on PPBUS_G3H?
Compare with values on all big coils; including L9080/580.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
What am I comparing on L9080? Like PP2V5_NAND_SSD1 to ground? to ppbus_g3h? to PP2V5_SW1_TPS62180_SSD1? Sorry for my ignorance.
ppbus_g3h to ground when I first touch its about 5ohms then drops to 3ohms after 2-3 seconds then settles around 2.5ohms, but when I hold it a long time (20+ seconds) it keeps creeping down, got down to 1.9 before I got too impatient after about a min.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
Allow 10-15s once power is removed, before checking in diode mode, or ohm scale, on any power rail.

Considering 3 ohm to ground at PPBUS_G3H and apñrox same reading on L9080 (or any other coil), you have two options when testing between PPBUS_G3H and L9080 (or other coil), in ohm scale: 6 ohm, or 0 ohm.
In other words, you will get the sum, or difference of the readings to ground.
If you get the reeadings difference , which can be 0 ohm in this example, then you have a short between PPBUS_G3H and corresponding coil.
It can be caused only by the power chip connected between both rails; an high-side MOSFET, or power IC.

In case of very low reading on a coil, you can also compare with good board.
3 ohm on L9080/580 is very bad; short for sure and damaged power IC, NAND chips, or filter capacitors.
However, CPU/GPU coils have very low resistance as normal.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:

Allow 10-15s once power is removed, before checking in diode mode, or ohm scale, on any power rail.

 This is minutes after power is disconnected. It will do this every time I check.

Diode mode between ppbus_g3h and L9080/580 is both .460

My thought was the short could be a mosfet because there was no discernible heat coming from anywhere on the board.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 100424, member: 682"]
Considering 3 ohm to ground at PPBUS_G3H and apñrox same reading on L9080 (or any other coil), you have two options when testing between PPBUS_G3H and L9080 (or other coil), in ohm scale: 6 ohm, or 0 ohm.
[/QUOTE]
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Mind explaining?

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
I'm an idiot, I really do apologize for wasting your time. A jumper I ran some time ago came loose when I was cleaning corrosion in the area and it seems I soldered it one pad over from where it should've been, a ground pad :|

Now to tackle yet another issue I created on this board. Some components by U4900 and U4920 blew away when I was removing U4920 to clean up a corrosive mess.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message: Turns out I did actually have it in the right spot. I'm so sick of this board. I removed CB702/3/4 as that's the area my jumper was in and PPBUS_G3H to ground is now 0.1ohms.

title: 820-01700 no backlight + other issues
message:
0.1 ohm shouldn't be through an high-side MOSFET, or power IC.
However, check first if you don't exact same short on any coil; don't forget L9080/580.
If none of them gives such short, then is safe to inject voltage into PPBUS_G3H.
Anyway, start with 1V and slowly increase if needed.
Set amp current to max first.
